messages.text: yeah, I think it has a warning if the checksums don't match
Am I right in thinking React will complain if it notices discrepancies while trying to render/diff into pre-existing `renderToString` DOM?
e.g. if whitespace/timestamps/whatever are different on that first client render, it's not gonna diff, it's just gonna replace everything
sure
Unless you have a form action for safe fallback i guess
<@U054QTMDH>: so you just need to be careful with render to string, that the first client render is _exactly_ the same as the server render
obviously in either case, until event handlers are bound, a form submission or something won't be handled properly until everything's ready
the downside of that being, if the user starts to interact with the page (input fields, selecting text) that'll get lost when that full re-render happens
if they differ at all, the checksum will not match, and the client will have to do a wholesale replace of everything

on the client, if you render into an element with a checksum, react will do the "virtual" render, checksum what it thinks needs to be rendered, and if they match, it will just attach event listeners etc
with render to string, react includes the data-react-id bits, as well as a checksum on the top level element
<@U054QTMDH>: to explain what happens, since I was just looking at this
interesting, ok. I guess I've been missing out! thanks <@U04QRFTK6> . will switch to renderToString()
so if you're running the same code on the client, then yes, you are somewhat <@U054QTMDH>

attachments.title: Bitwise operators
attachments.text: Bitwise operators treat their operands as a sequence of 32 bits (zeroes and ones), rather than as decimal, hexadecimal, or octal numbers. For example, the decimal number nine has a binary representation of 1001. Bitwise operators perform their operations on such binary representations, but they return standard JavaScript numerical values.

<@U07BH8HA7>: You could subscribe to your state changes using RxJS and then write observable queries to filter down to the sort of state changes you're interested in persisting to local storage.
